Option D. Portal hypertension: This condition would explain hepatomegaly and ascites but would not typically include pulmonary symptoms like crackles at the lung bases or findings like elevated JVP and positive hepatojugular reflux without concurrent heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constellation of symptoms such as elevated JVP, systemic edema (hepatomegaly, ascites, pedal edema), and pulmonary findings (crackles at the lung bases) strongly suggests heart failure, likely due to the patient's known history of hypertension and diabetes contributing to chronic cardiac stress and dysfunction.

 

Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complaints of intermenstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria gonorrhoea

 

The history of multiple sexual partners and lower abdominal pain with discharge and intermenstrual bleed suggests a diagnosis of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, of which cause can be N. Gonorrhoea among the given options.

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

 

 

Treatment –

 

KIT 6 (Yellow) – Tab Cefixime 400mg 1 Tab

 

  • Tab Metronidazole 400 mg (1 tab BD x 1 days)
  •  Tab Doxycycline 100 mg (1 tab BD x 21 days)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex causes painful genital ulcers.

 

Option B. Genital tuberculosis: Genital tuberculosis is seen in sexually inactive females

 

Option C. Vaginal candidiasis: Vaginal candidiasis presents as intense pruritus and white discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is most commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections, with Neisseria gonorrhoeae being a major pathogen, especially in women with multiple sexual partners presenting with lower abdominal pain and intermenstrual bleeding.

questions.text: Congenital lactic acidosis is due to the defect of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pyruvate dehydrogenase

 

Congenital lactic acidosis occurs when there is an accumulation of lactic acid in the body from birth, often due to a metabolic defect. In normal metabolism, glucose is converted to pyruvate through glycolysis. Under aerobic conditions, pyruvate is transported into the mitochondria, where it is converted into acetyl-CoA by the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase. Acetyl-CoA then enters the Krebs cycle to produce energy in the form of ATP.

 

When there is a deficiency or defect in the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme, pyruvate cannot be converted to acetyl-CoA. As a result, pyruvate accumulates and is instead converted to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis. Since this condition is present from birth, it is termed congenital lactic acidosis. Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is one of the key causes of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transketolase: This enzyme plays a role in the pentose phosphate pathway (also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt) and is not directly involved in the conversion of pyruvate or the production of lactic acid. Defects in transketolase do not lead to congenital lactic acidosis.

 

Option B. Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase: This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids and its deficiency causes Maple Syrup Urine Disease, not congenital lactic acidosis. It is unrelated to pyruvate metabolism.

 

Option C. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of the Krebs cycle, catalyzing the conversion of isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate. While it is involved in cellular respiration, defects in this enzyme are not responsible for congenital lactic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is a key cause of congenital lactic acidosis, as it prevents the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, leading to an accumulation of lactic acid.

questions.text: Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amniotic fluid embolism

 

  • The given clinical scenario with a diagnosis of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) points to amniotic fluid embolism as the most likely etiology.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism presents as 
    • hemodynamic and respiratory compromise, along with DIC.
    • Usually, it presents during the late stages of labor or immediate postpartum.
    • Gasping for air, seizures, and cardiorespiratory arrest are other features.

 

Diagnostic criteria for amniotic fluid embolism include:

 

  • Sudden onset cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • Overt DIC
  • Onset during labor or within 30 minutes of delivery of the placenta
  • No fever ≥38°C

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postpartum haemorrhage: This will present as vaginal bleeding followed by collapse/ DIC

 

Option C. Eclampsia: This will present as seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: This will present as cardiac failure following delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to amniotic fluid embolism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman visits the gynecology clinic for her routine check-up and cervical cancer screening. The gynecologist uses the instrument shown in the image for a pelvic examination to visualize the cervix and obtain a Pap smear. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cusco’s speculum

 

The instrument shown in the image is Cusco’s speculum, a self-retaining, bivalve speculum commonly used in gynecological examinations to visualize the cervix and vaginal fornices. It is frequently used for performing Pap smears and other routine gynecological procedures. Cusco’s speculum is advantageous because it is self-retaining, meaning it can stay in place without manual support, allowing the examiner to use both hands for other tasks. However, it provides limited space and may obscure the vaginal walls, making it unsuitable for some procedures where more visualization or access is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sims’ speculum: A non-self-retaining speculum used mainly in posterior vaginal wall prolapse and examination of vaginal lesions. It requires manual assistance to hold in place during the examination.

 

Option C. Auvard’s speculum: A weighted vaginal speculum primarily used in surgeries such as vaginal hysterectomy. It does not retain itself like Cusco’s speculum and is often used when extended retraction of the posterior vaginal wall is needed.

 

Option D. Graves’ speculum: Similar to Cusco’s but has wider, curved blades and is often used in examinations of patients with a larger vaginal canal. It is less commonly self-retaining and may require manual support.

 

Educational Objective:


Cusco’s speculum is a self-retaining bivalve instrument used to visualize the cervix during gynecological examinations, particularly useful for procedures like Pap smears. Its self-retaining nature provides ease during examinations, but it may limit access to other vaginal areas.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman experiences a 2-year history of infertility, as well as experiencing dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and is sensitive in the Douglas pouch. What should be the subsequent course of action in her management? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TVS

 

In this case, the initial step in the diagnostic evaluation of suspected endometriosis is transvaginal ultrasound (TVS). TVS is the first-line imaging modality used to assess pelvic structures and identify abnormalities such as endometriomas or nodularity in the pouch of Douglas. While laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis and allows for direct visualization and biopsy, it is generally reserved for cases where non-invasive methods are inconclusive or when surgical intervention is planned. TVS provides valuable initial information and helps in guiding further diagnostic and therapeutic steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Although laparoscopy is the definitive diagnostic procedure for endometriosis, it is not typically the first step. TVS is preferred initially to assess the presence of endometriosis-related changes and determine if more invasive procedures are necessary.

 

Option B. Laparotomy: Laparotomy is a more invasive surgical approach generally reserved for cases requiring larger abdominal incisions or when laparoscopy is not feasible. It is not typically used as an initial diagnostic tool for endometriosis.

 

Option C. HSG (Hysterosalpingography): HSG is used primarily to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes and uterine cavity. While it can assess tubal factor infertility, it does not provide information specific to endometriosis or the pelvic structures affected by it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of suspected endometriosis is to perform transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) to evaluate pelvic structures and identify abnormalities.

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all of the following except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fingerprint pattern

 

Monozygotic twins (Identical twins) are conceived when a single egg fertilized by a single sperm splits into two after fertilization. Such twins have 100% of their genes in common. Both of them invariably have the same blood type and are of the same sex.

 

 Dizygotic twins (Faternal twins) are conceived when two eggs are fertilized by two different sperms. They share 50% of their genes, just like any other siblings. Their blood types and sex can be either same or different.

 

So, all the inheritable characteristics will be exactly same in identical twins (e.g. Blood group, DNA fingerprinting, Iris Color).

 

But Fingerprints are not inheritable hence different even in identical twins. No finger-prints of 2 individuals are similar. It is 100% accurate method of identification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood Group: Identical twins invariably have the same blood type.

 

Option B. DNA Fingerprinting: Identical twins have identical DNA profiles because they share the same genetic material.

 

Option D. Iris Color: Iris color, being a genetic trait, will be the same in identical twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While identical twins share the same blood group, DNA fingerprinting, and iris color due to their identical genetic makeup, their fingerprint patterns are unique to each individual due to non-inheritable factors.

choices.text: The patient should undergo another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition.
There is a 2% prevalence of the disease in the population.
It is less likely that the patient has the disease.
The patient has been mistakenly ruled out due to a false negative result.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of persistent fatigue. The physician is concerned about a particular condition and orders an on-site diagnostic test to evaluate further. The test, known to have a sensitivity of 98%, returns a negative result. Based on the high sensitivity, what is the most likely implication of this negative test outcome for the patient? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) It is less likely that the patient has the disease. 

 

  • A negative result in a diagnostic test with a sensitivity of 98% implies that the patient is less likely to have the disease.
  • Sensitivity is the proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • It is the probability of the test being positive when the disease is present.
  • The sensitivity of a test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total diseased population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The patient should undergo another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition: The patient would not need another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition as the sensitivity of the diagnostic test is 98%.

 

Option B. There is a 2% prevalence of the disease in the population: Prevalence refers to the number of old and new cases at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It cannot be derived from the given data.

 

Option D. The patient has been mistakenly ruled out due to a false negative result: The higher the sensitivity of a diagnostic test, the lower will be the number of false negatives. Since the test has a 98% sensitivity, the patient most likely does not have the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A negative result in a highly sensitive test (98% sensitivity) makes it very unlikely that the patient has the disease, as false negatives are rare with such tests.

questions.text: The Epstein-Barr virus interacts with B cells via which of the following? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD21

 

  • The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) primarily infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor on the cell surface. CD21, also known as complement receptor 2 (CR2), is a receptor for the C3d fragment of the complement system and serves as the entry point for EBV into B cells. This interaction facilitates the virus's ability to infect and establish latency within B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CD20: This is a protein expressed on the surface of all B cells and is involved in B cell activation and proliferation. It is not used by EBV for cell entry.

 

Option C. CD19: This is a surface protein that acts as a co-receptor in B cell receptor signaling, but it is not directly involved in EBV entry.

 

Option D. CD23: This is the low-affinity receptor for IgE and does not play a role in EBV infection of B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor, which is the primary entry point for the virus into these cells.

questions.text: Below is the air pollution index chart for four consecutive days at the Delhi station. What is the categorization of the air quality index for November 23rd? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Severe

 

Based on the information provided in the query, the air quality index on November 23rd is measured at 407, falling under the severe category.

 

AIR QUALITY INDEX (AQI)

 

A tool used for effective communication of air quality status on a scale that is easily comprehensible. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

 

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI -

 

  1. PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  2. PM2.5 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  3. NO2 (Nitrogen dioxide)
  4. SO2 (Sulfur dioxide)
  5. CO (Carbon monoxide)
  6. 03 (Ozone/Trioxygen)
  7. NH3 (Ammonia)
  8. Pb (Lead)

 

AQl categories and the range are as follows:

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited by? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High estrogen


Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited primarily by high estrogen levels. Although prolactin, an anterior pituitary hormone, is responsible for stimulating milk production (lactogenesis), high levels of estrogen and progesterone during pregnancy prevent the secretion of milk. Estrogen promotes the development of the mammary glands but suppresses milk production. After childbirth, the levels of estrogen and progesterone drop, which allows prolactin to initiate and sustain milk secretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low luteinizing hormone: Incorrect. Luteinizing hormone (LH) is not directly involved in the regulation of milk production. The primary inhibitors are estrogen and progesterone.

 

Option C. Human somatomammotropin: Incorrect. Human somatomammotropin (also known as human placental lactogen) supports breast development and promotes milk production but does not inhibit it.

 

Option D. Low thyroid-stimulating hormone: Incorrect. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is not a primary factor in inhibiting milk production during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:


High estrogen levels inhibit milk production during pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page no 173, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4 - Lamina propria 

 

Is an incorrect match because the structure labelled 4 shows the basement membrane rather than the lamina propria.

 

The image shows irregular cells attached to the basement membrane and is of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (marked as 4 in the image). It appears to have multiple layers. There is, however, only one layer of cells. The multi-layered appearance is caused by the nuclei of epithelial cells (shown as 3 in the image) being located at different levels.1`

 

The epithelium shows hair-like projections called cilia (marked as 1 in the image) and goblet cells (marked as 2 in the image). Goblet cells secrete mucous which helps to trap dust entering the passages. The cilia are capable of movement and help in the clearance of mucous

 

Example include epithelium lining the trachea and in large bronchi.

 

Other Options:

 

1- Cilia: These are the hair-like projections visible at the top of the epithelial cells, which help in moving mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory passages.

 

2- Goblet cells: These cells are interspersed between the epithelial cells and are responsible for producing mucus. They appear as clear, expanded cells at the level marked "2."

 

3- Nuclei of epithelial cell: The nuclei shown here are located at different heights within the cells, giving the epithelium a pseudostratified appearance.

 

4- Basement membrane: This layer supports the epithelium and is incorrectly labeled as the lamina propria in the options. It is a thin, fibrous structure evident just below the epithelial cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The marked structure in the image are

 

1- Cilia

2- Goblet cell

3- Nuclei of epithelial cell

4- Basement membrane

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for the last eight months. A barium swallow test has been conducted, and the results are available for review. What further investigations are required for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry

 

The given scenario of long standing dysphagia in a 45 year old, with barium swallow showing smooth tapering is suggestive of achalasia. Next investigations would be upper GI endoscopy (to rule of cancer) and esophageal manometry (IOC).

 

  • Upper GI endoscopy: This procedure involves a visual examination of the esophagus, allowing the physician to see any obstructions, lesions, or abnormalities that could be causing dysphagia like cancer
  • Manometry: Manometry measures the pressures and coordinated muscle contractions of the esophagus. It's particularly helpful for conditions like achalasia, where there's an absence of normal esophageal peristalsis and increased lower esophageal sphincter tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper GI endoscopy & PET scan: While a PET scan can identify metabolic activity and might be useful in detecting metastasis, it isn't a first-line test for dysphagia. The primary concern with dysphagia is often mechanical or functional obstruction, which a PET scan wouldn't directly address.

 

Option C. Upper GI endoscopy & CECT: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) can provide images of the esophagus, but it is not the primary modality for evaluating dysphagia. While it can identify masses or structural issues, it doesn't offer functional insights like manometry.

 

Option D. Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring: 24-hour pH monitoring assesses the acidity in the esophagus over 24 hours. While it can be valuable for diagnosing conditions like GERD, it's not the primary investigation for dysphagia unless reflux symptoms are predominant

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the LES.
  • Manometry is the most sensitive test to diagnose achalasia and can identify early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention.
  • The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired LES relaxation, absent peristalsis, and elevated LES pressure. Subtypes are classified according to Chicago classification as Type 1 (classical), Type 2 (pan-esophageal pressurisation) and type 3 (Spastic).
  • Endoscopy can rule out pseudo achalasia/carcinoma.

questions.text: An individual seeks to explore the correlation between smoking and lung cancer. To do so, they gather information on individuals diagnosed with lung cancer from government hospitals, along with data on the quantity of cigarette packets sold during the corresponding timeframe. What category of study does this represent? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ecological

 

In the given study, the unit of study is the population, and the data collected by the investigator is secondary in nature. Therefore, this type of study is an ecological study, also known as a correlational study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cross-Sectional Study: Involves collecting data at a single point in time from individuals to assess the prevalence of an outcome or characteristic.

 

  • The unit of analysis is the individual, not the population.

 

Option C. Experimental Study: Involves the researcher manipulating one or more variables to observe the effect on an outcome.

 

  • There is no experimental intervention in the given study scenario.

 

Option D. Quasi-Experimental Study: Involves an intervention but lacks random assignment of participants to treatment or control groups.

 

  • Similar to experimental studies, quasi-experimental studies involve individuals, not population-level data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ECOLOGICAL STUDY / CO-RELATIONAL STUDY

 

  • Done at a point of time [E.g. in 2023]
  • Used in Nutritional surveys, e.g. à Avg. fat intake = 20gm/day
  • Can’t calculate strength of Association or Prevalence
  • Based on secondary data [collected by someone else, studied by investigator]

questions.text: Which type of virus is rubella? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Togavirus

 

Rubella belongs to the Togaviridae family.

 

Rubella (German measles)

 

  • Causative organism belongs to family Togaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks
  • Rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post infectious thrombocytopenia
  • Most serious complication: Encephalitis
  • Vaccination: 27/3 live attenuated

 

Congenital rubella syndrome:

 

  • When a woman in the 1st trimester gets infected with rubella, the resulting complications may include miscarriage, fetal death, premature delivery, or live birth with congenital defects.
  • The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataract, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome.
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term "blueberry muffin syndrome."

 

Expanded rubella syndrome:

 

  • Some babies present with several other features like hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions constituting the expanded rubella syndrome.
  • This term also refers to a baby with metastatic neuroblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flavivirus: This group includes viruses like the West Nile virus and Dengue virus, not Rubella.

 

Option C. Paramyxovirus: Includes viruses like measles and mumps, which are clinically distinct from rubella.

 

Option D. Orthomyxovirus: This is the family of viruses that includes the influenza viruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rubella, commonly known as German measles, is caused by a virus that belongs to the Togaviridae family, specifically the genus Rubivirus. This virus is typically transmitted via respiratory droplets and primarily causes a mild infection characterized by a rash, low fever, and swollen glands. However, its most significant health impact occurs when a pregnant woman is infected, particularly in the first trimester, leading to congenital rubella syndrome.

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate Caesarean section

 

  •  The patient is a case of 
    • Preeclampsia 
    • Twin pregnancy (1st twin breech)
  • She is 38 weeks
  • As she is preeclamptic and has crossed 37 weeks, treatment would be to deliver her immediately. 
  • As the 1st twin is non cephalic, the mode of delivery is a cesarean delivery. 
  • Indications of cesarean delivery in multiple pregnancy:        
    • 1st twin non cephalic
    • Monoamniotic monochorionic twins
    • Conjoined twins
    • Triplets and above

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monitor BP and terminate if BP rises: There is no indication to wait any longer as even in mild pre-eclampsia, delivery is done at 37 weeks. Waiting any longer is simply subjecting both mother and fetus to risks.

 

Option C. Terminate at 40 weeks: Again, this should not be done as in pre-eclampsia, delivery is planned at 37 weeks (mild) and 34 weeks (severe). This patient is already 38 weeks gestation

 

Option D. Induce labor with PGE2 gel: This patient should be delivered by cesarean section as she has twin babies, the 1st of twin is breech (non-cephalic). This becomes an indication for an elective LSCS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of preeclampsia with twin pregnancies where the first twin is in a breech position at 38 weeks, immediate cesarean section is the recommended course of action.

 

Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition
